entry.title: Proof-of-Stake Bitcoin Sidechains
entry.summary:
The correspondence delves into the intricacies of designing a system where Bitcoin, or specifically the holding of it, could grant voting power within a certain framework. The sender clarifies that their proposed design remains neutral regarding the origin of voting authority, thus allowing flexibility in determining how stake or membership in the validator set is derived. This openness paves the way for innovative approaches to integrating Bitcoin into governance mechanisms.
A notable idea presented is the concept of utilizing timelocked Bitcoin as a means to allocate voting power. This proposition stems from the desire to directly tie the act of holding Bitcoin to the ability to influence decisions within the system. Despite the appeal of this approach, concerns are raised regarding the non-slashable nature of Bitcoin. In traditional systems, validators face the risk of having their stake slashed (i.e., penalized) if they act maliciously, such as by double-signing. However, since Bitcoin itself cannot be confiscated in this manner, an alternative punitive measure suggested involves blacklisting a validator's Unspent Transaction Output (UTXO). This measure seeks to impose a cost on malicious actions by depriving the attacker of the time-value associated with their staked Bitcoin, thereby introducing financial disincentives for betrayal.
Further contemplation is given to the potential of rewarding stake to those who participate in Bitcoin merged-mining. This idea represents an ongoing exploration into how Bitcoinâ€™s existing infrastructure and mechanisms can be leveraged to support new forms of stake-based governance. The sender expresses a commitment to further investigate the viability of timelocked Bitcoin as a source of stake, indicating an ongoing process of refinement and consideration aimed at harnessing Bitcoin's unique properties to enhance voting systems.
